4 Basic Data Types
==================

This chapter defines a number of common data types used in the definitions of SVG properties and attributes. Some data types that are not referenced by multiple properties and attributes are defined inline in subsequent chapters.

<boolean>

A boolean value, specified as either 'true' or 'false'.

<Char>

A character, as defined by the [Char](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/#dt-character) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/) (\[[XML10](#refs-ref-XML10)\], section 2.2), or the [Char](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/#dt-character) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/) (\[[XML11](#refs-ref-XML11)\], section 2.2) if the document is an XML 1.1 document.

<Clock-value>

An amount of time, used by various attributes on [timed elements](#intro-TermTimedElement). The grammar describing possible values for a [<Clock-value>](#types-DataTypeClock-value) is given in the [Clock values](#animate-ClockValueSyntax) section of the [Animation](#chapter-animate) chapter.

<color>

The basic type [<color>](#types-DataTypeColor) defines a color within the sRGB color space \[[SRGB](#refs-ref-SRGB)\]. The [<color>](#types-DataTypeColor) type is used as the value of the ['color'](#painting-ColorProperty) property and is a component of the definitions of properties ['fill'](#painting-FillProperty), ['stroke'](#painting-StrokeProperty), ['stop-color'](#painting-StopColorProperty), ['solid-color'](#painting-SolidColorElement) and ['viewport-fill'](#painting-viewport-fill-property).

All of the syntax alternatives for [<color>](#types-DataTypeColor) defined in [Syntax for color values](#painting-colorSyntax) must be supported. All RGB colors are specified in the sRGB color space \[[SRGB](#refs-ref-SRGB)\]. Using sRGB provides an unambiguous and objectively measurable definition of the color, which can be related to international standards \[[COLORIMETRY](#refs-ref-COLORIMETRY)\].

<content-type>

An Internet media type, as per [Multipart Internet Mail Extensions: (MIME) Part Two: Media Types](http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2046.txt) \[[RFC2046](#refs-ref-RFC2046)\].

<coordinate>

A [<coordinate>](#types-DataTypeCoordinate) is a length in the [user coordinate system](#intro-TermUserCoordinateSystem) that is the given distance from the origin of the user coordinate system along the relevant axis (the x-axis for X coordinates, the y-axis for Y coordinates). Its syntax is the same as that for [<length>](#types-DataTypeLength).

<focus>

The type of value that can be used in the various [navigation attributes](#intro-TermNavigationAttribute), such as ['nav-next'](#interact-NavNextAttribute), ['nav-prev'](#interact-NavPrevAttribute), etc. See [Specifying navigation](#interact-specifyingnavigation) for the definition of the values that can be used in those attributes.

<font-family-value>

A list of font family names and generic names. Specifically, this is the type of value that can be used for the ['font-family'](#text-FontFamilyProperty) property, excluding the 'inherit' value.

<family-name>

A single font family name as given by a [<family-name>](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xsl11-20061205/#font-family), as defined in Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL) Version 1.1 (\[[XSL](#refs-ref-XSL)\], section 7.9.2).

<font-size-value>

A value that can be used for the ['font-size'](#text-FontSizeProperty) property, excluding the 'inherit' value.

<FuncIRI>

Functional notation for an [IRI](#intro-TermIRIReference): "url(" [<IRI>](#types-DataTypeIRI) ")".

<ID>

The type of value that can be used in an XML attribute of type ID (such as ['id'](#struct-IDAttribute) and ['xml:id'](#struct-xmlIDAttribute)); that is, a string matching the [Name](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/#NT-Name) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/) (\[[XML10](#refs-ref-XML10)\], section 2.3), or the [Name](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/#NT-Name) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/) (\[[XML11](#refs-ref-XML11)\], section 2.3) if the document is an XML 1.1 document.

<IDREF>

The type of value that can be used in an XML attribute of type IDREF (such as ['observer'](#script-observer-attr)); that is, a string matching the [Name](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/#NT-Name) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/) (\[[XML10](#refs-ref-XML10)\], section 2.3), or the [Name](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/#NT-Name) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/) (\[[XML11](#refs-ref-XML11)\], section 2.3) if the document is an XML 1.1 document.

<integer>

An <integer> is specified as an optional sign character ("+" or "-") followed by one or more digits "0" to "9". If the sign character is not present, the number is non-negative.

<integer> values in conforming SVG Tiny 1.2 content must be within the range of -32,768 to 32,767, inclusive.

<IRI>

An Internationalized Resource Identifier (see [IRI](#intro-TermIRIReference)). For the specification of [IRI](#intro-TermIRIReference) references in SVG, see [IRI references](#linking-IRIReference).

<language-id>

The type of value accepted by the ['xml:lang'](#struct-XMLLangAttribute) attribute as defined in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/) (\[[XML10](#refs-ref-XML10)\], section 2.12) and [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/) (\[[XML11](#refs-ref-XML11)\], section 2.12). Specifically, this is either a language tag as defined by [BCP 47](http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/bcp/bcp47.txt) (\[[BCP 47](#refs-ref-BCP47)\], section 2) or the empty string.

<length>

A length is a distance measurement. The format of a <length> is a [<number>](#types-DataTypeNumber) optionally followed by a unit identifier. If the <length> is expressed as a value without a unit identifier (e.g., '48'), then the <length> represents a distance in the current [user coordinate system](#intro-TermUserCoordinateSystem).

SVG Tiny 1.2 only supports optional units on the ['width'](#struct-SVGElementWidthAttribute) and ['height'](#struct-SVGElementHeightAttribute) attributes on the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element. These can specify values in any of the following units: in, cm, mm, pt, pc, px and %. If one of the unit identifiers is provided (e.g., '12mm'), then the <length> is processed according to the description in [Units](#coords-Units).

Percentage values (e.g., '10%') on the ['width'](#struct-SVGElementWidthAttribute) and ['height'](#struct-SVGElementHeightAttribute) attributes of the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element represent a percentage of the [viewport](#intro-TermViewport) size (refer to the section that discusses [Units](#coords-Units) in general).

<list-of-content-types>

A space-separated list of Internet media types, as used by the ['requiredFormats'](#struct-RequiredFormatsAttribute) attribute.

The following is an EBNF grammar describing the <list-of-content-types> syntax \[[EBNF](#refs-ref-EBNF)\]:

list-of-content-types ::= [content-type](#types-DataTypeContentType)
                          | [content-type](#types-DataTypeContentType) wsp list-of-content-types
wsp                   ::= (#x9 | #xD | #xA | #x20)\*

<list-of-family-names>

A <list-of-family-names> is a list of font family names using the same syntax as the ['font-family'](#text-FontFamilyProperty) property, excluding the <generic-family> and 'inherit' values.

<list-of-language-ids>

A <list-of-language-ids> is a comma separated list of non-empty [<language-id>](#types-DataTypeLanguageID) values. White space may be used before or after the commas.

<list-of-strings>

A <list-of-strings> consists of a separated sequence of [<string>](#types-DataTypeString)s. String lists are white space-separated, where white space is defined as one or more of the following consecutive characters: "space" (U+0020), "tab" (U+0009), "line feed" (U+000A) and "carriage return" (U+000D).

The following is an EBNF grammar describing the <list-of-strings> syntax \[[EBNF](#refs-ref-EBNF)\]:

list-of-strings ::= [string](#types-DataTypeString)
                    | [string](#types-DataTypeString) wsp list-of-strings
wsp             ::= (#x9 | #xD | #xA | #x20)\*

<list-of-Ts>

(Where T is a type other than [<content-type>](#types-DataTypeContentType), [<string>](#types-DataTypeString), [<language-id>](#types-DataTypeLanguageID) and [<family-name>](#types-DataTypeFamilyName).) A list consists of a separated sequence of values. Unless explicitly described differently, each pair of list items can be separated either by a comma (with optional whitespace before and after the comma) or by white space alone.

White space in lists is defined as one or more of the following consecutive characters: "space" (U+0020), "tab" (U+0009), "line feed" (U+000A) and "carriage return" (U+000D).

The following is a template for an EBNF grammar describing the <list-of-Ts> syntax \[[EBNF](#refs-ref-EBNF)\]:

list-of-Ts ::= T
               | T comma-wsp list-of-Ts
comma-wsp ::= (wsp+ comma? wsp\*) | (comma wsp\*)
comma     ::= ","
wsp       ::= (#x9 | #xD | #xA | #x20)

Substituting a type other than [<content-type>](#types-DataTypeContentType), [<string>](#types-DataTypeString), [<language-id>](#types-DataTypeLanguageID) and [<family-name>](#types-DataTypeFamilyName) for T will yield a grammar for a list of that type.

<long>

A <long> is specified as an optional sign character ("+" or "-") followed by one or more digits "0" to "9". If the sign character is not present, the number is non-negative.

<long> values in conforming SVG Tiny 1.2 content must be within the range of -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647, inclusive.

<NCName>

An XML name without colons, as defined by the [NCName](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names-20060816/#NT-NCName) production in [Namespaces in XML 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names-20060816/) (\[[XML-NS10](#refs-ref-XML-NS10)\], section 3), or the [NCName](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names11-20060816/#NT-NCName) production in [Namespaces in XML 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names11-20060816/) (\[[XML-NS](#refs-ref-XML-NS)\], section 3) if the document is an XML 1.1 document.

<number>

A <number> value is specified in either decimal or scientific notation. A <number> using decimal notation consists of either an [<integer>](#types-DataTypeInteger), or an optional sign character followed by zero or more digits followed by a dot (.) followed by one or more digits. Using scientific notation, it consists of a number in decimal notation followed by the letter "E" or "e", followed by an [<integer>](#types-DataTypeInteger).

The following is an EBNF grammar describing the <number> syntax \[[EBNF](#refs-ref-EBNF)\]:

number            ::= decimal-number | scientific-number
decimal-number    ::= [integer](#types-DataTypeInteger)
                      | ("+" | "-")? \[0-9\]\* "."  \[0-9\]+
scientific-number ::= decimal-number \[Ee\] [integer](#types-DataTypeInteger)

<number> values in conforming SVG Tiny 1.2 content must have no more than 4 decimal digits in the fractional part of their decimal expansion and must be in the range -32,767.9999 to +32,767.9999, inclusive. It is recommended that higher precision floating point storage and computation be performed on operations such as coordinate system transformations to provide the best possible precision and to prevent round-off errors.

<paint>

The values for properties ['fill'](#painting-FillProperty) and ['stroke'](#painting-StrokeProperty) are specifications of the type of paint to use when filling or stroking a given [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement). The available options and syntax for <paint> are described in [Specifying paint](#painting-SpecifyingPaint).

<path-data>

The <path-data> type is used to represent path data, as can be specified in the ['d'](#paths-DAttribute) attribute on a ['path'](#paths-PathElement) element. See the [detailed description of path data](#paths-PathData), including the [grammar for path data](#paths-PathDataBNF).

<points-data>

The <points-data> type is used to represent a list of points, as can be specified in the ['points'](#shapes-PolylineElementPointsAttribute) attribute on a ['polyline'](#shapes-PolylineElement) or ['polygon'](#shapes-PolygonElement) element. See the [grammar for points data](#shapes-PointsBNF).

<QName>

The <QName> type is a qualified name, as defined by the [QName](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names-20060816/#NT-QName) production in [Namespaces in XML 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names-20060816/) (\[[XML-NS10](#refs-ref-XML-NS10)\], section 3), or the [QName](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names11-20060816/#NT-QName) production in [Namespaces in XML 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names11-20060816/) (\[[XML-NS](#refs-ref-XML-NS)\], section 3) if the document is an XML 1.1 document. If the <QName> has a prefix, then the prefix is expanded into a tuple of an [IRI reference](#intro-TermIRIReference) and a local name, using the namespace declarations in effect where the name occurs. Note that, as with unprefixed attributes, the default namespace is _not_ used for unprefixed names.

<string>

A sequence of zero or more [<Char>](#types-DataTypeChar)s.

<transform>

A <transform> is a transformation specification, as can be specified in the ['transform'](#coords-TransformAttributeDefinition) attribute. As described in [The 'transform' attribute](#coords-TransformAttribute), three types of values are allowed: a transform list, a transform reference and the 'none' value.

The following is an EBNF grammar describing the <transform> syntax \[[EBNF](#refs-ref-EBNF)\]:

transform ::= [transform-list](#coords-TransformList) | [transform-ref](#coords-transform-ref) | "none"

<XML-Name>

An XML name, as defined by the [Name](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/#NT-Name) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/) (\[[XML10](#refs-ref-XML10)\], section 2.3), or the [Name](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/#NT-Name) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/) (\[[XML11](#refs-ref-XML11)\], section 2.3) if the document is an XML 1.1 document.

<XML-NMTOKEN>

An XML name token, as defined by the [Nmtoken](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/#NT-Nmtoken) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/) (\[[XML10](#refs-ref-XML10)\], section 2.3), or the [Nmtoken](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/#NT-Nmtoken) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/) (\[[XML11](#refs-ref-XML11)\], section 2.3) if the document is an XML 1.1 document.

<XML-NMTOKENS>

An space separated sequence of XML name tokens, as defined by the [Nmtokens](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/#NT-Nmtokens) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/) (\[[XML10](#refs-ref-XML10)\], section 2.3), or the [Nmtokens](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/#NT-Nmtokens) production in [Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/) (\[[XML11](#refs-ref-XML11)\], section 2.3) if the document is an XML 1.1 document.

5.1 Defining an SVG document fragment: the 'svg' element
--------------------------------------------------------

### 5.1.1 Overview

An [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment) consists of any number of [SVG elements](#intro-TermSVGElement) contained within an ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element, including the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element.

An [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment) can range from an empty fragment (i.e., no content inside of the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element), to a very simple [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment) containing a single SVG [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement) such as a ['rect'](#shapes-RectElement), to a complex, deeply nested collection of [container elements](#intro-TermContainerElement) and [graphics elements](#intro-TermGraphicsElement).

An [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment) can stand by itself as a self-contained file or resource, in which case the [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment) is an SVG document, or it can be embedded inline as a fragment within a parent XML document.

The following example shows simple SVG content embedded inline as a fragment within a parent XML document. Note the use of XML namespaces to indicate that the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) and ['ellipse'](#shapes-EllipseElement) elements belong to the SVG namespace:

**Example:** 05\_01.xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<parent xmlns="http://example.org"
        xmlns:svg="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
   <!-- parent contents here -->
   <svg:svg width="4cm" height="8cm" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny" viewBox="0 0 100 100">
      <svg:ellipse cx="50" cy="50" rx="40" ry="20" />
   </svg:svg>
   <!-- ... -->
</parent>

This example shows a slightly more complex (i.e., it contains multiple rectangles) stand-alone, self-contained SVG document:

**Example:** [05\_02.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_02.svg)

﻿<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="5cm" height="4cm" viewBox="0 0 100 100">

  <desc>Four separate rectangles</desc>

  <rect x="20" y="20" width="20" height="20"/>
  <rect x="50" y="20" width="30" height="15"/>
  <rect x="20" y="50" width="20" height="20"/>
  <rect x="50" y="50" width="20" height="40"/>

  <!-- Show outline of canvas using 'rect' element -->
  <rect x="1" y="1" width="98" height="98"
        fill="none" stroke="blue" stroke-width="2" />
</svg>

An [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment) can only contain one single ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element, this means that ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) elements cannot appear in the middle of SVG content.

In all cases, for compliance with either the [Namespaces in XML 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names-20060816/) or [Namespaces in XML 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names11-20060816/) Recommendations \[[XML-NS10](#refs-ref-XML-NS10), [XML-NS](#refs-ref-XML-NS)\], an SVG namespace declaration must be in scope for the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element, so that all [SVG elements](#intro-TermSVGElement) are identified as belonging to the SVG namespace.

For example, an 'xmlns' attribute without a prefix could be specified on an ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element, which means that SVG is the default namespace for all elements within the scope of the element with the 'xmlns' attribute:

**Example:** 05\_03.svg

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny">
  <desc>Demonstrates use of a default namespace prefix for elements.</desc>
  <rect width="7" height="3"/>
</svg>

If a namespace prefix is specified on the 'xmlns' attribute (e.g., `xmlns:svg="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg")`, then the corresponding namespace is not the default namespace, so an explicit namespace prefix must be assigned to the elements:

**Example:** 05\_04.svg

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<s:svg xmlns:s="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny">
  <s:desc>Demonstrates use of a namespace prefix for elements.
    Notice that attributes are not namespaced</s:desc>
  <s:rect width="7" height="3"/>
</s:svg>

Namespace declarations can also be specified on ancestor elements (illustrated in [example 05\_01, above](#struct-EmbeddedSVGExample)). For more information, refer to the [Namespaces in XML 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names-20060816/) or [Namespaces in XML 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-names11-20060816/) Recommendations \[[XML-NS10](#refs-ref-XML-NS10), [XML-NS](#refs-ref-XML-NS)\].

### 5.1.2 The 'svg' element

**Schema:** svg

    <define name='svg'>
      <element name='svg'>
        <ref name='svg.AT'/>
        <zeroOrMore><ref name='svg.G.group'/></zeroOrMore>
      </element>
    </define>

    <define name='svg.AT' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.Properties.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.FocusHighlight.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.External.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Focus.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.AnimateSyncDefault.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Core.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.WH.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.PAR.attr'/>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='viewBox' svg:animatable='true' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <text/>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='zoomAndPan' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value>disable</value>
            <value>magnify</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='version' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value type='string'>1.0</value>
            <value type='string'>1.1</value>
            <value type='string'>1.2</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='baseProfile' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value type='string'>none</value>
            <value type='string'>tiny</value>
            <value type='string'>basic</value>
            <value type='string'>full</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='contentScriptType' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <ref name='ContentType.datatype'/>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='snapshotTime' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value type='string'>none</value>
            <ref name='Clock-value.datatype'/>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='timelineBegin' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value type='string'>onLoad</value>
            <value type='string'>onStart</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='playbackOrder' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value type='string'>all</value>
            <value type='string'>forwardOnly</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
    </define>

_Attribute definitions:_

1.  version = "1.0" | "1.1" | "1.2"

    Indicates the SVG language version to which this document fragment conforms.

    In SVG 1.0 and SVG 1.1 this attribute had the value '1.0' or '1.1' respectively, and SVG 1.2 adds the value '1.2'. See [rules for version processing](#implnote-VersionControl) for further instructions, notably on handling of [unsupported values](#intro-TermUnsupportedValue).

    Modifying the 'version' attribute using the DOM does not cause any change in behavior. In this case, the original value of the attribute is the one used for document processing.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

2.  baseProfile = "none" | "full" | "basic" | "tiny"

    Describes the minimum SVG language profile that the author believes is necessary to correctly render the content. See [rules for baseProfile processing](#implnote-VersionControl) for further instructions.

    This specification defines the values 'none' and 'tiny'. The value 'full' corresponds to all features in the SVG language; for SVG 1.1, this corresponds to the language features defined in the [SVG 1.1 Specification](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/) \[[SVG11](#refs-ref-SVG11)\]. The value 'basic' was defined in the [Mobile SVG Profiles: SVG Tiny and SVG Basic](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVGMobile11/) \[[SVGM11](#refs-ref-SVGM11)\]. This specification corresponds to baseProfile="tiny" and version="1.2". A value of 'none' provides no information about the minimum language profile that is necessary to render the content.

    The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is 'none'.

    Modifying the 'baseProfile' attribute using the DOM does not cause any change in behavior. In this case, the original value of the attribute is the one used for document processing.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

3.  width = "[<length>](#types-DataTypeLength)"

    The intrinsic width of the [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment). Together with the ['height'](#struct-SVGElementHeightAttribute), ['viewBox'](#coords-ViewBoxAttribute) and ['preserveAspectRatio'](#coords-PreserveAspectRatioAttribute) attributes it defines the intrinsic aspect ratio and (unless both width and height are percentages) the intrinsic size of the svg element. See [The initial viewport](#coords-InitialViewport).

    A negative value is [unsupported](#intro-TermUnsupportedValue). A value of zero disables rendering of the element.

    The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is '100%'.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

4.  height = "[<length>](#types-DataTypeLength)"

    The intrinsic height of the [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment).

    A negative value is [unsupported](#intro-TermUnsupportedValue). A value of zero disables rendering of the element.

    The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is '100%'.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

5.  viewBox = "[<list-of-numbers>](#types-DataTypeList)" | "none"

    See [attribute definition](#coords-ViewBoxAttribute) for description.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

6.  preserveAspectRatio = "\[defer\] <align> \[<meet>\]"

    See [attribute definition](#coords-PreserveAspectRatioAttribute) for description.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

7.  snapshotTime = "[<clock-value>](#types-DataTypeClock-value)" | "none"

    Indicates a moment in time which is most relevant for a still-image of the animated SVG content. This time may be used as a hint to the [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) for rendering a still-image of an animated SVG document, such as a preview. A value of 'none' means that no 'snapshotTime' is available. See [example 05\_22](#struct-SnapshotTimeExample) for an example of using the 'snapshotTime' attribute.

    The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is 'none'.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

8.  playbackOrder = "forwardOnly" | "all"

    Indicates whether it is possible to seek backwards in the document. In earlier versions of SVG there was no need to put restrictions on the direction of seeking but with the newly introduced facilities for long-running documents (e.g. the ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element) there is sometimes a need to restrict this.

    If 'playbackOrder' is set to 'forwardOnly', the content will probably contain ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) elements or scripts that destroy resources, thus seeking back in the document's timeline may result in missing content. If 'playbackOrder' is 'forwardOnly', the content should not provide a way, through hyperlinking or script, of seeking backwards in the timeline. Similarly the UA should disable any controls it may provide in the user interface for seeking backwards. Content with 'playbackOrder' = 'forwardOnly' that provides a mechanism for seeking backwards in time may result in undefined behavior or a document that is [in error](#intro-TermInError).

9.  'forwardOnly'

    This file is intended to be played only in the forward direction, sequentially, therefore seeking backwards should not be allowed.

10. 'all'

    Indicates that the document is authored appropriately for seeking in both directions.

    The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is 'all'.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

11. timelineBegin = "onLoad" | "onStart"

    Controls the initialization of the timeline for the document.

    The ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element controls the _document timeline_, which is the timeline of the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element's time container. For progressively loaded animations, the author would typically set this attribute to 'onStart', thus allowing the timeline to begin as the document loads, rather than waiting until the complete document is loaded.

12. 'onLoad'

    The document's timeline starts the moment the [`load`](#interact-LoadEvent) event for the [rootmost 'svg' element](#intro-TermRootmostSVGElement) is triggered.

13. 'onStart'

    The document's timeline starts at the moment the [rootmost 'svg' element](#intro-TermRootmostSVGElement)'s _start-tag_ ([as defined in XML 1.0](http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/REC-xml-20060816/#sec-starttags) (\[[XML10](#refs-ref-XML10)\], section 3.1), [or XML 1.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-xml11-20040204/#sec-starttags) (\[[XML11](#refs-ref-XML11)\], section 3.1), if the document is an XML 1.1 document) is fully parsed and processed.

    The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is 'onLoad'.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

14. contentScriptType = "[<content-type>](#types-DataTypeContentType)"

    Identifies the default scripting language for the given document. This attribute sets the default scripting language for all the instances of script in the document fragment. This language must be used for all scripts that do not specify their own scripting language. The [<content-type>](#types-DataTypeContentType) value specifies a media type, per [Multipart Internet Mail Extensions: (MIME) Part Two: Media Types](http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2046.txt) \[[RFC2046](#refs-ref-RFC2046)\]. The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is "application/ecmascript".

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

15. zoomAndPan = "magnify" | "disable"

    See [attribute definition](#interact-ZoomAndPanAttribute) for description.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

16. focusable = "true" | "false" | "auto"

    See [attribute definition](#interact-focusable-attr) for description.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

17. Navigation Attributes

    See [definition](#interact-specifyingnavigation).

Note that ['animateMotion'](#animate-AnimateMotionElement) and ['animateTransform'](#animate-AnimateTransformElement) are legal as children to ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) but don't apply to their ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) parent (since the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element doesn't have a ['transform'](#coords-TransformAttribute) attribute). They only have any effect if the ['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) attribute is specified so that they target a different element for animation.

Content produced by illustration programs originally targeted at print often has a fixed width and height, which will prevent it scaling for different display resolutions. The first example below has a fixed width and height in pixels, and no ['viewBox'](#coords-ViewBoxAttribute).

**Example:** [width-height.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/width-height.svg)

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="300px" height="600px">
  <desc>...</desc>
</svg>

Normally, SVG content is designed to be scalable. In order for the SVG content to scale automatically to fill the available [viewport](#intro-TermViewport), it must include a ['viewBox'](#coords-ViewBoxAttribute) attribute on the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element. This describes the region of world coordinate space (the initial [user coordinate system](#intro-TermUserCoordinateSystem)) used by the graphic. This attribute thus provides a convenient way to design SVG documents to scale-to-fit into an arbitrary [viewport](#intro-TermViewport).

The second example is scalable, using a ['viewBox'](#coords-ViewBoxAttribute) rather than a fixed width and height.

**Example:** [viewBox.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/viewBox.svg)lesource">

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" 
     baseProfile="tiny" viewBox="0 0 300 600">
  <desc>...</desc>
</svg>

Below is an example of ['snapshotTime'](#struct-SVGElementSnapshotTimeAttribute). An [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) is displaying a number of SVG files in a directory by rendering a thumbnail image. It uses the ['snapshotTime'](#struct-SVGElementSnapshotTimeAttribute) as the time to render when generating the image, thus giving a more representative static view of the animation. The appearance of the thumbnail for an [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) that honors the ['snapshotTime'](#struct-SVGElementSnapshotTimeAttribute) and for an [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) that does not is shown below the example (UA which generates thumbnails based on ['snapshotTime'](#struct-SVGElementSnapshotTimeAttribute) at the left, UA which doesn't generate thumbnails based on ['snapshotTime'](#struct-SVGElementSnapshotTimeAttribute) at the right, e.g. a static viewer).

**Example:** [05\_22.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_22.svg)

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     viewBox="0 0 400 300" snapshotTime="3">

  <title>Snapshot time example</title>
  <desc>This example shows the use of snapshotTime on an animation of color.</desc>

  <rect x="60" y="85" width="256" height="65" fill="none" stroke="rgb(60,126,220)" stroke-width="4"/>
    
  <text x="65" y="140" fill="white" font-size="60">
    Hello SVG
    <animateColor attributeName="fill" begin="0" dur="3" from="white" to="rgb(60,126,220)"/>  
  </text> 
</svg>

![Snapshot time thumbnails](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/struct/snapshotTime01.png)

5.2 Grouping: the 'g' element
-----------------------------

### 5.2.1 Overview

The ['g'](#struct-GElement) element is a [container element](#intro-TermContainerElement) for grouping together related [graphics elements](#intro-TermGraphicsElement).

Grouping constructs, when used in conjunction with the ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) and ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) elements, provide information about document structure and semantics. Documents that are rich in structure may be rendered graphically, as speech, or as braille, and thus promote [accessibility](#chapter-access).

A group of elements, as well as individual objects, can be given a name using the ['id'](#struct-IDAttribute) or ['xml:id'](#struct-xmlIDAttribute) attribute. Named groups are needed for several purposes such as animation and re-usable objects.

An example:

**Example:** [05\_05.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_05.svg)

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="5cm" height="5cm" viewBox="0 0 5 5">

  <desc>Two groups, each of two rectangles</desc>

  <g xml:id="group1" fill="red">
    <desc>First group of two red rectangles</desc>
    <rect x="1" y="1" width="1" height="1"/>
    <rect x="3" y="1" width="1" height="1"/>
  </g>
  <g xml:id="group2" fill="blue">
    <desc>Second group of two blue rectangles</desc>
    <rect x="1" y="3" width="1" height="1"/>
    <rect x="3" y="3" width="1" height="1"/>
  </g>

  <!-- Show outline of canvas using 'rect' element -->
  <rect x=".01" y=".01" width="4.98" height="4.98"
        fill="none" stroke="blue" stroke-width=".02"/>
</svg>

A ['g'](#struct-GElement) element can contain other ['g'](#struct-GElement) elements nested within it, to an arbitrary depth. Thus, the following is possible:

**Example:** 05\_06.svg

﻿<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="5cm" height="5cm">

  <desc>Groups can nest</desc>

  <g>
    <g>
      <g>
      </g>
    </g>
  </g>
</svg>

Any element that is not contained within a ['g'](#struct-GElement) is treated (at least conceptually) as if it were in its own group.

### 5.2.2 The 'g' element

**Schema:** g

    <define name='g'>
      <element name='g'>
        <ref name='g.AT'/>
        <zeroOrMore><ref name='svg.G.group'/></zeroOrMore>
      </element>
    </define>

    <define name='g.AT' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.Properties.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.FocusHighlight.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Core.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.External.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Conditional.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Focus.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Transform.attr'/>
    </define>

_Attribute definitions:_

*   focusable = "true" | "false" | "auto"

    See [attribute definition](#interact-focusable-attr) for description.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

*   Navigation Attributes

    See [definition](#interact-specifyingnavigation).

5.3 The 'defs' element
----------------------

The 'defs' element is a [container element](#intro-TermContainerElement) for referenced elements. For understandability and [accessibility](#chapter-access) reasons, it is recommended that, whenever possible, referenced elements be defined inside of a ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement). For performance reasons, authors should put the ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement) element before other document content, so that all resources are available to be referenced.

The content model for ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement) is the same as for the ['g'](#struct-GElement) element; thus, any element that can be a child of a ['g'](#struct-GElement) can also be a child of a ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement), and vice versa.

Elements that are descendants of a ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement) are not rendered directly; they are prevented from becoming part of the [rendering tree](#intro-TermRenderingTree) just as if the ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement) element were a ['g'](#struct-GElement) element and the ['display'](#painting-DisplayProperty) property were set to none. Note, however, that the descendants of a ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement) are always present in the source tree and can be referenced by other elements. The actual value of the ['display'](#painting-DisplayProperty) property on the ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement) element or any of its descendants does not change the rendering of these elements or prevent these elements from being referenced.

**Schema:** defs

    <define name='defs'>
      <element name='defs'>
        <ref name='defs.AT'/>
        <zeroOrMore><ref name='svg.G.group'/></zeroOrMore>
      </element>
    </define>

    <define name='defs.AT' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.Properties.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Core.attr'/>
    </define>

Creators of SVG content are encouraged to place all elements which are targets of local [IRI reference](#intro-TermIRIReference)s (except of course for animation targets) within a ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement) element which is a direct child of one of the ancestors of the referencing element. For example:

**Example:** [05\_10.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_10.svg)

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 8 3">     

  <desc>Local URI references within ancestor's 'defs' element.</desc>

  <defs>
    <linearGradient xml:id="Gradient01">
      <stop offset="0.2" stop-color="#39F"/>
      <stop offset="0.9" stop-color="#F3F"/>
    </linearGradient>
  </defs>

  <rect x="1" y="1" width="6" height="1" fill="url(#Gradient01)"/>

  <!-- Show outline of canvas using 'rect' element -->
  <rect x=".01" y=".01" width="7.98" height="2.98"
        fill="none" stroke="blue" stroke-width=".02" />
</svg>

In the document above, the linear gradient is defined within a ['defs'](#struct-DefsElement) element which is the direct child of the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element, which in turn is an ancestor of the ['rect'](#shapes-RectElement) element which references the linear gradient. Thus, the above document conforms to the guideline.

5.4 The 'discard' element
-------------------------

The ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element allows authors to specify the time at which particular elements are to be discarded, thereby reducing the resources required by an [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent). This is particularly useful to help SVG viewers conserve memory while displaying long-running documents. This element will not be processed by static SVG viewers.

The ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element may occur wherever the ['animate'](#animate-AnimateElement) element may.

**Schema:** discard

    <define name='discard'>
      <element name='discard'>
        <ref name='discard.AT'/>
        <ref name='discard.CM'/>
      </element>
    </define>

    <define name='discard.AT' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.Core.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.XLink.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.AnimateBegin.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Conditional.attr'/>
    </define>

    <define name='discard.CM'>
      <zeroOrMore>
        <ref name='svg.Desc.group'/>
        <ref name='svg.Handler.group'/>
      </zeroOrMore>
    </define>

_Attribute definitions:_

1.  xlink:href = "[<IRI>](#types-DataTypeIRI)"

    An [IRI reference](#linking-IRIReference) that identifies the [target element](#animate-TargetElement) to discard. See the definition of ['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) on [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement) for details on identifying a target element.

    Note that if the target element is not part of the [current SVG document fragment](#intro-TermCurrentSVGDocumentFragment) then whether the target element will be removed or not is defined by the [host language](#intro-TermHostLanguage).

    If the ['xlink:href'](#struct-DiscardElementHrefAttribute) attribute is not provided, then the target element will be the immediate parent element of the discard element.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

2.  begin = "_begin-value-list_"

    Indicates when the target element will be discarded. See the definition of ['begin'](#animate-BeginAttribute) on [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement) for details.

    The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is '0s'. This indicates that the [target element](#animate-TargetElement) should be discarded immediately once the document begins.

    [Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

The ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element has an implicit [simple duration](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-DefiningSimpleDur) of "indefinite". As soon as the element's [active duration](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-ComputingActiveDur) starts, the [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) discards the element identified by the ['xlink:href'](#struct-DiscardElementHrefAttribute) attribute (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.3). The removal operation acts as if the method [`removeChild`](#svgudom-dom__Node_removeChild) were called on the parent of the target element with the target element as parameter. The [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) must remove the target node as well as all of its attributes and descendants.

After removal of the [target element](#animate-TargetElement), the ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element is no longer useful. It must also be discarded following the target element removal. If the ['xlink:href'](#struct-DiscardElementHrefAttribute) attribute has an [invalid IRI reference](#intro-TermInvalidIRIReference) (the target element did not exist, for example), the ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element itself must still be removed following activation.

[Seeking backwards](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-HyperlinksAndTiming) in the timeline (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.3) must not re-insert the discarded elements. Discarded elements are intended to be completely removed from memory. So, authors are encouraged to set the ['playbackOrder'](#struct-SVGElementPlaybackOrder) attribute to "forwardOnly" when using the ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element.

The ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element itself can be discarded prior to its activation, in which case it will never trigger the removal of its own target element. [SVG user agents](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) must allow the ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element to be the target of another ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element.

The following example demonstrates a simple usage of the ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element. The list below describes relevant behavior in the document timeline of this example:

1.  At time = 0:

    When the document timeline starts, the blue ellipse starts to move down the page.

2.  At time = 1 second:

    The red rectangle starts moving up the page.

3.  At time = 2 seconds:

    The ['animateTransform'](#animate-AnimateTransformElement) on the ['ellipse'](#shapes-EllipseElement) ends. The ['ellipse'](#shapes-EllipseElement) and its children are also discarded, as it is the [target element](#animate-TargetElement) of a ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) with begin="2". The green ['polygon'](#shapes-PolygonElement) starts to move across the page.

4.  At time = 3 seconds:

    The animation on the red rectangle ends. The rectangle and its children are discarded as it is the target of a ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element with begin="3".

5.  At time = 4 seconds:

    The animation on the green triangle ends. The green ['polygon'](#shapes-PolygonElement) and its children are discarded as it is the target of a ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element with begin="4".

**Example:** [discard01.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/discard01.svg)

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny" 
     width="352" height="240" playbackOrder="forwardOnly">
    
  <ellipse cx="98.5" cy="17.5" rx="20.5" ry="17.5" fill="blue" stroke="black" 
           transform="translate(9 252) translate(3 -296)">
    <animateTransform attributeName="transform" begin="0s" dur="2s" fill="remove"
                      calcMode="linear" type="translate" additive="sum"
                      from="0 0" to="-18 305"/>
    <discard begin="2s"/>
  </ellipse>
  
  <rect x="182" y="-39" width="39" height="30" fill="red" stroke="black"
        transform="translate(30 301)">
    <animateTransform attributeName="transform" begin="1s" dur="2s" fill="remove"
                      calcMode="linear" type="translate" additive="sum"
                      from="0 0" to="-26 -304"/>
    <discard begin="3s"/>
  </rect>
  
  <polygon points="-66,83.5814 -43,123.419 -89,123.419" fill="green" stroke="black" 
           transform="matrix(1 0 0 1.1798 0 -18.6096)">
    <animateTransform attributeName="transform" begin="2s" dur="2s"
                      fill="remove" calcMode="linear" type="translate" additive="sum"
                      from="0 0" to="460 63.5699"/>
    <discard begin="4s"/>
  </polygon>
</svg>

5.5 The 'title' and 'desc' elements
-----------------------------------

Each [container element](#intro-TermContainerElement) or [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement) in an SVG document may contain one or more of each of the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement), which together comprise a sort of heading and summary of the containing element. The ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) element must contain a brief plain text passage representing the title for the [container](#intro-TermContainerElement) or [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement) containing it. This short title must provide information supplementary to the rendering of the element, but will normally not be sufficient to replace it. The ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) element must contain a longer, more detailed plain text description for the [container](#intro-TermContainerElement) or [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement) containing it. This description, along with the content of the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) element, must be usable as replacement content for cases when the user cannot see the rendering of the [SVG element](#intro-TermSVGElement) for whatever reason.

Authors should always provide at least a ['title'](#struct-TitleElement), and preferably a ['desc'](#struct-DescElement), as an immediate child element to the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element within an SVG document, and to every significant individual graphical composition within the document. The ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) child element to an ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element serves the purposes of identifying the content of the given [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment). Since users often consult documents out of context, authors should provide context-rich titles. Thus, instead of a title such as "Introduction", which doesn't provide much contextual background, authors should supply a title such as "Introduction to Medieval Bee-Keeping" instead. For reasons of accessibility, [SVG user agents](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) should always make the content of the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) child element to the ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element available to users (See the User Agent Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 \[[UAAG](http://www.w3.org/TR/UAAG10/)\]). The mechanism for doing so depends on the [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) (e.g., as a caption, spoken). If for any reason, a graphical presentation of the document is not available, the rootmost [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) may represent the complete document and its purpose in a textual manner, and authors should supply meaningful content accordingly.

When [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) are present, alternate presentations of the document are possible, both visual and aural, which display the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) elements but do not display [graphics elements](#intro-TermGraphicsElement).

For both the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and the ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) element, the content must be plain text. To provide structured data in other markup languages, authors should use the ['metadata'](#metadata-MetadataElement) or ['foreignObject'](#extend-ForeignObjectElement) elements instead, as appropriate. When markup is included as a child of the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) or the ['desc'](#struct-DescElement), a [user agent](#intro-TermUserAgent) should present only the text content of the [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement).

Note that the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) element is distinct in purpose from the ['xlink:title'](#linking-XLinkTitleAttribute) attribute of the ['a'](#linking-AElement) element. The ['xlink:title'](#linking-XLinkTitleAttribute) attribute content is intended not to describe the current resource, but the nature of the linked resource.

**Schema:** title

    <define name='title'>
      <element name='title'>
        <ref name='DTM.AT'/>
        <ref name='DTM.CM'/>
      </element>
    </define>

**Schema:** desc

    <define name='desc'>
      <element name='desc'>
        <ref name='DTM.AT'/>
        <ref name='DTM.CM'/>
      </element>
    </define>

    <define name='DTM.AT' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.Core.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Conditional.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Media.attr'/>
    </define>

    <define name='DTM.CM'>
      <text/>
    </define>

### 5.5.1 Applicable 'title' and 'desc'

Normally, the [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) that describe a [container element](#intro-TermContainerElement) or [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement) are direct children of that element. However, SVG documents can have a rich structure, with nested elements each potentially containing ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) or ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) child elements, as well as ['use'](#struct-UseElement) elements with ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) or ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) in both the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element itself and in the referenced content. Because of this complex structure, and because the [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) may or may not be present at any given level, the applicable [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) for any given content is determined by the structure, as described here.

For each [container element](#intro-TermContainerElement) or [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement), the applicable [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) shall be those which are most shallowly nested in that document fragment, without taking into account [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) in any ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element [shadow trees](#intro-TermShadowTree). If the document fragment has no [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement), and it is a ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element, the applicable [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) shall be those contained in the [shadow tree](#intro-TermShadowTree). If no [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) are found in the document fragment or any [shadow tree](#intro-TermShadowTree), the applicable [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) shall be the nearest ancestor [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement). This algorithm allows authors to reuse [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) defined in referenced resources when desired, or to override them as needed, as well as to describe whole groups of elements. Note that the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) are not necessarily always paired (i.e., in the same document hierarchy level), and if the user agent should stop searching for an applicable [descriptive element](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) if only one or the other is encountered at a particular hierarchy level.

Note that the applicable [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) for elements in a [container element](#intro-TermContainerElement) does not necessarily entail a description of the individual graphical elements in question, but rather their membership in a more inclusive group (e.g., if the image is of a basket of fruit, with a title of "Fruit Basket" for the containing group and no other [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement), while no one piece of fruit is a fruit basket, the title would still be applicable through inclusion). In essence, there is a difference between [container elements](#intro-TermContainerElement) and [graphics elements](#intro-TermGraphicsElement) when it comes to determining the applicability of a [descriptive element](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement); a ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) or ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) for a [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement) should be assumed to apply only to that element, while a ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) or ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) for a ['g'](#struct-GElement) may apply to each of the children of that group. Authors should take care to designate all important elements with their own [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) to avoid misconstrued identities and entailments.

### 5.5.2 Multiple 'title' and 'desc' elements

It is strongly recommended that authors use at most one ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and at most one ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) element as an immediate child of any particular element, and that these elements appear before any other child elements (except possibly ['metadata'](#metadata-MetadataElement) elements) or character data content.

Authors may wish to deliberately provide multiple [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement), such as to provide alternate content for different languages. In this case, the author should use [conditional processing attributes](#intro-TermConditionalProcessingAttribute) to allow the user agent to select the best choice according to the user's preferences. For example, the ['systemLanguage'](#struct-SystemLanguageAttribute) attribute, with or without the ['switch'](#struct-SwitchElement) element, will determine the applicable [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement).

If an [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) needs to choose among multiple ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) or ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) elements for processing (e.g., to decide which string to use for a tooltip), and if any available [conditional processing attributes](#intro-TermConditionalProcessingAttribute) are insufficient to resolve the best option, the [user agent](#intro-TermUserAgent) must choose the first of each of the available [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) as the applicable ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and ['desc'](#struct-DescElement).

### 5.5.3 User interface behavior for 'title' and 'desc'

When the [current SVG document fragment](#intro-TermCurrentSVGDocumentFragment) is rendered as SVG on visual media, ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) elements are not rendered as part of the [canvas](#intro-TermCanvas). Often, the intent of authors is for [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) to remain hidden (e.g., for aesthetic reasons in pieces of art). However, other authors may wish for this content to be displayed, and providing tangible benefit to these authors encourages best practice in providing [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement). In this case, authors are encouraged to use the ['role'](#struct-RoleAttribute) attribute, with the value [tooltip](http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/#tooltip) (\[[ARIA](#refs-ref-ARIA)\], section 4.4.1) to indicate their intent. Future SVG specifications may define an explicit mechanism for indicating whether a tooltip should be displayed.

In order to honor authorial intent, it is strongly recommended that when, and only when, the appropriate ['role'](#struct-RoleAttribute) attribute value is present, [user agents](#intro-TermUserAgent) display the text content of the applicable ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) elements in a highly visible manner supported by the user agent, such as in a tooltip or status bar, when the pointing device is hovered over the described element or elements, or when the described element is given focus (e.g., through keyboard or pointer navigation). If a tooltip is provided, the user agent is recommended to display the applicable title and descriptions on separate lines, title first, with font styling that distinguishes the two. For long descriptions, the tooltip may wrap the text, and truncate longer passages to a reasonable length. A user agent may preserve spaces and line breaks in the text content in order to structure the presentation of the text.

When an element with [descriptive elements](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) is itself the child of an ['a'](#linking-AElement) element with an ['xlink:title'](#linking-XLinkTitleAttribute) attribute, the user agent should display as much of the available information as possible. The user agent is suggested to display the ['xlink:title'](#linking-XLinkTitleAttribute) attribute value on a separate line, with a label to identify it, such as "link: ". Commonly, many user agents display the URI of the link (i.e., the value of the ['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) attribute) in the status bar or other display area. This information is important, and should not be overridden by any [descriptive element](#intro-TermDescriptiveElement) content, but may be supplemented by such content.

The rootmost ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) element should be used as the document title, and for stand-alone SVG documents, the title should not be displayed as a tooltip, but rather in the browser chrome (as appropriate for the user agent). For embedded SVG documents, such as an SVG image referenced in an HTML document, displaying the rootmost title and description as a tooltip is more appropriate, and the user agent should do so.

If a user agent is an accessibility tool, all available descriptions of the currently focused or hovered element should be exposed to the user in a categorical manner, such that the user may selectively access the various descriptions. The ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) element, in particular, may be given different semantic distinctions by use of values in the ['role'](#struct-RoleAttribute) attribute, such as the [ARIA](http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/ "Accessible Rich Internet Applications (WAI-ARIA)    Version 1.0") ontology value [description](http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/#description) (\[[ARIA](#refs-ref-ARIA)\], section 4.4.1) for textual equivalents of the graphics (the default role).

The following is an example in which an [SVG user agent](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) might present the ['title'](#struct-TitleElement) and ['desc'](#struct-DescElement) elements as a tooltip.

**Example:** [title-desc-tooltip.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/title-desc-tooltip.svg)

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
     version="1.2"
     width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 160 170">

  <title>Titles and Descriptions</title>
  <desc>An example of how the contents of the 'title' and 'desc' elements may be presented in a user agent.</desc>

  <defs>
    <polygon id="beeCell" points="-14,-24.2487 14,-24.2487 28,0 14,24.2487 -14,24.2487 -28,0" stroke="yellow" stroke-width="3" stroke-linejoin="round">
      <title role="tooltip">Beehive cell</title>
      <desc role="tooltip">A simple hexagon with a yellow outline and no fill.</desc>
    </polygon>
  </defs>

  <g fill="white">
    <use xlink:href="#beeCell" x="30" y="60" />
    <use xlink:href="#beeCell" x="75" y="34.0192" />
    <use xlink:href="#beeCell" x="120" y="60" />
    <use xlink:href="#beeCell" x="120" y="111.9615" />
    <use xlink:href="#beeCell" x="30" y="111.9615" />
    <use xlink:href="#beeCell" x="75" y="137.9423" />

    <a xlink:href="http://www.example.com/bees.html" xlink:title="Beekeeper's Hive: an apiary resource">
      <title role="tooltip">Link to Beekeeper's Hive: an apiary resource</title>
      <use xlink:href="#beeCell" x="75" y="85.9808" fill="#9900CC">
        <title role="tooltip">Queen's Cell</title>
        <desc role="tooltip">
          A hexagonal beehive cell.
          
          A purple hexagon in the middle of 6 other empty hexagons, symbolizing that it's filled with royal jelly.
        </desc>
      </use>
    </a>  
     
  </g>

</svg>

5.6 The 'use' element
---------------------

Any ['g'](#struct-GElement) or [graphics element](#intro-TermGraphicsElement) is potentially a template object that can be re-used (i.e. "instantiated") in the SVG document via a ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element, thus creating an instance tree. The ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element references another element and indicates that the graphical contents of that element is to be included and drawn at that given point in the document.

Unlike ['animation'](#multimedia-AnimationElement), the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element cannot reference entire files.

Besides what is described about the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element in this section important restrictions for ['use'](#struct-UseElement) can be found in the [Reference Section](#linking-ReferenceRestrictions).

The ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element has optional attributes ['x'](#struct-UseElementXAttribute) and ['y'](#struct-UseElementYAttribute) which are used to place the referenced element and its contents into the current coordinate system.

The effect of a ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element is as if the [SVG element](#intro-TermSVGElement) contents of the referenced element were deeply cloned into a separate non-exposed DOM tree which had the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element as its parent and all of the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element's ancestors as its higher-level ancestors. Because the cloned DOM tree is non-exposed, the SVG Document Object Model (DOM) only contains the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element and its attributes. The SVG DOM does not show the referenced element's contents as children of the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element. The deeply-cloned tree, also referred to as the [shadow tree](#intro-TermShadowTree), is then kept in synchronization with the contents of the referenced element, so that any animation, DOM manipulation, or non-DOM interactive state occurring on the referenced element are also applied to the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element's deeply-cloned tree.

Relative [IRIs](#intro-TermIRIReference) on a node in a [shadow tree](#intro-TermShadowTree) are resolved relative to any ['xml:base'](#struct-XMLBaseAttribute) on the node itself, then recursively on any ['xml:base'](#struct-XMLBaseAttribute) on its [`parentNode`](#svgudom-dom__Node_parentNode), and finally any ['xml:base'](#struct-XMLBaseAttribute) on the [`ownerDocument`](#svgudom-dom__Node_ownerDocument) if there is no [`parentNode`](#svgudom-dom__Node_parentNode).

Property inheritance works as if the referenced element had been textually included as a deeply cloned child of the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element. The referenced element inherits properties from the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element and the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element's ancestors. An instance of a referenced element does not inherit properties from the referenced element's original parents.

The behavior of the ['visibility'](#painting-VisibilityProperty) property conforms to this model of property inheritance. Thus, a computed value of visibility="hidden" on a ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element does not guarantee that the referenced content will not be rendered. If the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element has a computed value of visibility="hidden" and the element it references specifies visibility="hidden" or visibility="inherit", then that element will be hidden. However, if the referenced element instead specifies visibility="visible", then that element will be visible even if the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element specifies visibility="hidden".

If an event listener is registered on a referenced element, then the actual target for the event will be the [SVGElementInstance](#svgudom-svg__SVGElementInstance) object within the "instance tree" corresponding to the given referenced element.

The event handling for the non-exposed tree works as if the referenced element had been textually included as a deeply cloned child of the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element, except that events are dispatched to the [SVGElementInstance](#svgudom-svg__SVGElementInstance) objects. The event's [`target`](#svgudom-events__Event_target) and [`currentTarget`](#svgudom-events__Event_currentTarget) attributes are set to the [SVGElementInstance](#svgudom-svg__SVGElementInstance) that corresponds to the target and current target elements in the referenced subtree. An event propagates through the exposed and non-exposed portions of the tree in the same manner as it would in the regular document tree: first going to the target of the event, then bubbling back through non-exposed tree to the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element and then back through regular tree to the [rootmost 'svg' element](#intro-TermRootmostSVGElement) in the bubbling phase.

An element and all its corresponding [SVGElementInstance](#svgudom-svg__SVGElementInstance) objects share an event listener list. The [`currentTarget`](#svgudom-events__Event_currentTarget) attribute of the event can be used to determine through which object an event listener was invoked.

Animations on a referenced element will cause the instances to also be animated.

As listed in the [Reference Section](#linking-ReferenceRestrictions) the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element is not allowed to reference an ['svg'](#struct-SVGElement) element.

Except for resolution of relative [IRI references](#intro-TermIRIReference) as noted and until the referenced elements are modified, a ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element has the same visual effect as if the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element were replaced by the following generated content:

*   In the generated content, the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) will be replaced by ['g'](#struct-GElement), where all attributes from the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element except for ['x'](#struct-UseElementXAttribute), ['y'](#struct-UseElementYAttribute), ['xml:base'](#struct-XMLBaseAttribute) and ['xlink:href'](#linking-xlinkRefAttrs) are transferred to the generated ['g'](#struct-GElement) element. An additional transformation translate(x,y) is appended to the end (i.e., right-side) of the ['transform'](#coords-TransformAttribute) attribute on the generated ['g'](#struct-GElement), where x and y are the values of the ['x'](#struct-UseElementXAttribute) and ['y'](#struct-UseElementYAttribute) attributes of the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element. The referenced object and its contents are deep-cloned into the generated tree.

Note also that any changes to the used element are _immediately_ reflected in the generated content.

When a ['use'](#struct-UseElement) references another element which is another ['use'](#struct-UseElement) or whose content contains a ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element, then the deep cloning approach described above is recursive. However, a set of references that directly or indirectly reference a element to create a circular dependency is an [error](#intro-TermInError), as described in the [References](#linking-IRIReference) section.

**Schema:** use

    <define name='use'>
      <element name='use'>
        <ref name='use.AT'/>
        <ref name='use.CM'/>
      </element>
    </define>

    <define name='use.AT' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.Properties.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.FocusHighlight.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Core.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Conditional.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Transform.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.XLinkEmbed.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Focus.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.External.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.XY.attr'/>
    </define>

    <define name='use.CM'>
      <zeroOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name='svg.Desc.group'/>
          <ref name='svg.Animate.group'/>
          <ref name='svg.Handler.group'/>
        </choice>
      </zeroOrMore>
    </define>

_Attribute definitions:_

x = "[<coordinate>](#types-DataTypeCoordinate)"

The x-axis coordinate of one corner of the rectangular region into which the referenced element is placed.

The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is '0'.

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

y = "[<coordinate>](#types-DataTypeCoordinate)"

The y-axis coordinate of one corner of the rectangular region into which the referenced element is placed.

The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is '0'.

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

xlink:href = "[<IRI>](#types-DataTypeIRI)"

An [IRI reference](#intro-TermIRIReference) to an element/fragment within an SVG document. An [invalid IRI reference](#intro-TermInvalidIRIReference) is an [unsupported value](#intro-TermUnsupportedValue). An empty attribute value (xlink:href="") disables rendering of the element. The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is the empty string.

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

focusable = "true" | "false" | "auto"

See [attribute definition](#interact-focusable-attr) for description.

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): yes.

Navigation Attributes

See [definition](#interact-specifyingnavigation).

Below are two examples of the ['use'](#struct-UseElement) element. For another example see [use and animation example](#linking-useVsAnimationExample).

Example 05\_13 below has a simple ['use'](#struct-UseElement) on a ['rect'](#shapes-RectElement).

**Example:** [05\_13.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_13.svg)

﻿<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
     version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="10cm" height="3cm" viewBox="0 0 100 30">     

  <desc>Simple case of 'use' on a 'rect'</desc>

  <defs>
    <rect xml:id="MyRect" width="60" height="10"/>
  </defs>
  <rect x=".1" y=".1" width="99.8" height="29.8"
        fill="none" stroke="blue" stroke-width=".2"/>
  <use x="20" y="10" xlink:href="#MyRect" />
</svg>

![Rendering of 05_13.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_13.png)

The visual effect would be equivalent to the following document:

**Example:** [05\_14.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_14.svg)

﻿<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" 
     version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="10cm" height="10cm" viewBox="0 0 100 30">

  <desc>
    The equivalent rendering tree of example 05\_13 once the
    'use' element's shadow tree has been created.
  </desc>

  <!-- 'defs' section left out -->

  <rect x=".1" y=".1" width="99.8" height="29.8"
        fill="none" stroke="blue" stroke-width=".2" />

  <!-- begin shadow tree content that the <use> element in the original
       file would generate -->
  <g transform="translate(20,10)">
    <rect width="60" height="10"/>
  </g>
  <!-- end of shadow tree content -->
</svg>

Example 05\_17 illustrates what happens when a ['use'](#struct-UseElement) has a ['transform'](#coords-TransformAttribute) attribute.

**Example:** [05\_17.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_17.svg)

﻿<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
     version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="10cm" height="3cm" viewBox="0 0 100 30">

  <desc>'use' with a 'transform' attribute</desc>

  <defs>
    <rect xml:id="MyRect" x="0" y="0" width="60" height="10"/>
  </defs>

  <rect x=".1" y=".1" width="99.8" height="29.8"
        fill="none" stroke="blue" stroke-width=".2"/>
  <use xlink:href="#MyRect" transform="translate(20,2.5) rotate(10)"/>
</svg>

![Rendering of 05_17.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_17.png)

The visual effect would be equivalent to the following document:

**Example:** [05\_18.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/05_18.svg)

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
     version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"
     width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 100 30">

  <desc>'use' with a 'transform' attribute</desc>

  <!-- 'defs' section left out -->

  <rect x=".1" y=".1" width="99.8" height="29.8"
        fill="none" stroke="blue" stroke-width=".2"/>

  <!-- begin shadow tree content that the <use> element in the original
       file would generate -->
  <g transform="translate(20,2.5) rotate(10)">
    <rect x="0" y="0" width="60" height="10"/>
  </g>
  <!-- end of shadow tree content-->
</svg>

Example use-bubble-example-1.svg illustrates four cases of event bubbling with use elements. In case 1, all instances of the ['rect'](#shapes-RectElement) element are filled blue on mouse over. For cases 2 and 3, in addition to the ['rect'](#shapes-RectElement) elements being filled blue, a black stroke will also appear around the referencing rectangle on mouse over. In case 4, all the rectangles turn blue on mouse over, and a black stroke appears on mouse click.

**Example:** [use-bubble-example-1.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/use-bubble-example-1.svg)

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
     xmlns:ev="http://www.w3.org/2001/xml-events"
     version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny">

  <defs>
    <rect id="rect" width="20" height="20" fill="red">
      <set attributeName="fill" begin="mouseover" end="mouseout" to="blue"/>
    </rect>
  </defs>

  <use fill="red" x="5" y="5" xlink:href="#rect"/>
  <text x="10" y="35">1</text>
  
  <use id="use2" fill="red" x="30" y="5" xlink:href="#rect"/>  
  <rect pointer-events="none" x="30" y="5" width="20" height="20"
        fill="none" stroke-width="3" stroke="none">
    <set attributeName="stroke" begin="use2.mouseover" end="use2.mouseout" to="black"/>
  </rect>
  <text x="35" y="35">2</text>
  
  <g id="g1">
    <use fill="red" x="5" y="40" xlink:href="#rect"/>  
    <rect pointer-events="none" x="5" y="40" width="20" height="20"
          fill="none" stroke-width="3" stroke="none">
      <set attributeName="stroke" begin="g1.mouseover" end="g1.mouseout" to="black"/>
    </rect>
  </g>
  <text x="10" y="70">3</text>
  
  <use id="use3" fill="red" x="30" y="40" xlink:href="#rect"/>  
  <rect pointer-events="none" x="30" y="40" width="20" height="20"
        fill="none" stroke-width="3" stroke="none">
    <set attributeName="stroke" begin="use3.click" dur="500ms" to="black"/>
  </rect>  
  <text x="35" y="70">4</text>
</svg>

![Rendering of use-bubble-example-1.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/use-bubble-example-1.png)

Example use-bubble-example-2.svg illustrates event bubbling with nested ['use'](#struct-UseElement) elements. On mouse over, the ['rect'](#shapes-RectElement) element is filled blue and displays a green and black ring.

**Example:** [use-bubble-example-2.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/use-bubble-example-2.svg)

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
     xmlns:ev="http://www.w3.org/2001/xml-events"
     version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny">

  <defs>
    <rect id="rect" width="20" height="20" fill="red">
      <set attributeName="fill" begin="mouseover" end="mouseout" to="blue"/>
    </rect>    
    <g id="use">
      <use fill="red" xlink:href="#rect"/>  
      <rect pointer-events="none" width="20" height="20"
            fill="none" stroke-width="8" stroke="none">
        <set attributeName="stroke" begin="use.mouseover" end="use.mouseout" to="green"/>
      </rect>
    </g>
  </defs>
  
  <use x="5" y="5" id="use2" fill="red" xlink:href="#use"/>  
  <rect pointer-events="none" x="5" y="5" width="20" height="20" fill="none" stroke-width="3" stroke="none">
    <set attributeName="stroke" begin="use2.mouseover" end="use2.mouseout" to="black"/>
  </rect>
</svg>

![Rendering of use-bubble-example-2.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/use-bubble-example-2.png)

Example image-use-base.svg illustrates the handling of relative [IRI references](#intro-TermIRIReference). All three use elements result in the same image being displayed, `http://a.example.org/aaa/bbb/ddd/foo.jpg`.

**Example:** [image-use-base.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/image-use-base.svg)

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"
     version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny" viewBox="00 100 100">

  <g xml:base="http://a.example.org/aaa/">
    <g xml:base="/bbb/ccc/">
      <g xml:base="../ddd/" xml:id="bar">
        <image xml:id="foo" xlink:href="foo.jpg" width="100" height="100"/>
      </g>
