16.1 Introduction
-----------------

SVG supports the ability to change vector graphics over time. SVG content can be animated in the following ways:

*   Using SVG's [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement). [SVG document fragments](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment) can describe time-based modifications to the document's elements. Using the various animation elements, you can define motion paths, fade-in or fade-out effects, and objects that grow, shrink, spin or change color.
*   Using the [SVG uDOM](#chapter-svgudom). The SVG uDOM conforms to the [Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3](http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Core/) specification \[[DOM3](#refs-ref-DOM3)\]. Some of the SVG attributes are accessible to scripting and by manipulating them many kind of animations can be achieved. The timer facility in the [uDOM](#chapter-svgudom) can be used to start up and control the animations. (See [example](#animate-DOMAnimationExample) below.)

16.2 Animation elements
-----------------------

### 16.2.1 Overview

SVG's animation elements were developed in collaboration with the W3C Synchronized Multimedia (SYMM) Working Group, developers of the [Synchronized Multimedia Integration Language (SMIL) 2.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/) Specification \[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\].

SVG incorporates the animation features defined in the SMIL 2.1 specification and provides some SVG-specific extensions.

For an introduction to the approach and features available in any language that supports SMIL 2.1 animation, see the [Introduction](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-Introduction) and [animation sandwich model](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-AnimationSandwichModel) sections of the [SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], sections 3.2 and 3.3.3). For the list of animation features which go beyond SMIL Animation, see [SVG extensions to SMIL 2.1 Animation](#animate-SVGExtensionsToSMILAnimation) below.

### 16.2.2 Relationship to SMIL 2.1 Animation

SVG is a host language in terms of SMIL 2.1 Animation and therefore introduces additional constraints and features as permitted by that specification. Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for SVG's [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement) and attributes are those in the [SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html) and the [SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html) chapter (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], sections 3 and 10). Note that the SMIL timing engine is orthogonal to the rendering tree.

SVG supports the following four animation elements which are defined in the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules:

  

['animate'](#animate-AnimateElement)

  

allows scalar attributes and properties to be assigned different values over time

  

['set'](#animate-SetElement)

  

a convenient shorthand for ['animate'](#animate-AnimateElement), which is useful for assigning animation values to non-numeric attributes and properties, such as the ['visibility'](#painting-VisibilityProperty) property

  

['animateMotion'](#animate-AnimateMotionElement)      

  

moves an element along a motion path

  

['animateColor'](#animate-AnimateColorElement)

  

modifies the color value of particular attributes or properties over time

Additionally, SVG includes the following compatible extensions to SMIL 2.1:

  

['animateTransform'](#animate-AnimateTransformElement)

  

modifies one of SVG's transformation attributes over time, such as the ['transform'](#coords-TransformAttribute) attribute

  

['path'](#animate-PathAttribute) attribute

  

allows any feature from SVG's [path data](#paths-PathData) syntax to be specified in a ['path'](#animate-PathAttribute) attribute to the ['animateMotion'](#animate-AnimateMotionElement) element (SMIL 2.1 Animation only allows a subset of SVG's path data syntax within a ['path'](#paths-PathElement) attribute)

  

['mpath'](#animate-MpathElement) element

  

allows an ['animateMotion'](#animate-AnimateMotionElement) element to contain a child ['mpath'](#animate-MpathElement) element which references an SVG ['path'](#paths-PathElement) element as the definition of the motion path

  

['keyPoints'](#animate-KeyPointsAttribute) attribute

  

adds a ['keyPoints'](#animate-KeyPointsAttribute) attribute to the ['animateMotion'](#animate-AnimateMotionElement) to provide precise control of the velocity of motion path animations

  

['rotate'](#animate-RotateAttribute) attribute

  

adds a ['rotate'](#animate-RotateAttribute) attribute to the ['animateMotion'](#animate-AnimateMotionElement) to control whether an object is automatically rotated so that its x-axis points in the same direction (or opposite direction) as the directional tangent vector of the motion path

For compatibility with other aspects of the language, SVG uses [IRI references](#intro-TermIRIReference) via an ['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) attribute to identify the elements which are to be targets of the animations.

SMIL 2.1 Animation requires that the host language define the meaning for [document begin](#intro-TermDocumentBegin) and [document end](#intro-TermDocumentEnd), and these are defined in the [Definitions](#intro-Definitions) section.

### 16.2.3 Animation elements example

Example anim01 below demonstrates each of SVG's five [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement).

**Example:** [19\_01.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/19_01.svg)

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svg width="8cm" height="3cm"  viewBox="0 0 800 300"
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny">
  <desc>Example anim01 - demonstrate animation elements</desc>
  <rect x="1" y="1" width="798" height="298" 
        fill="none" stroke="blue" stroke-width="2" />
  <!-- The following illustrates the use of the 'animate' element
        to animate a rectangles x, y, and width attributes so that
        the rectangle grows to ultimately fill the viewport. -->
  <rect xml:id="RectElement" x="300" y="100" width="300" height="100"
        fill="rgb(255,255,0)"  >
    <animate attributeName="x" 
             begin="0s" dur="9s" fill="freeze" from="300" to="0" />
    <animate attributeName="y" 
             begin="0s" dur="9s" fill="freeze" from="100" to="0" />
    <animate attributeName="width" 
             begin="0s" dur="9s" fill="freeze" from="300" to="800" />
    <animate attributeName="height" 
             begin="0s" dur="9s" fill="freeze" from="100" to="300" />
  </rect>
  <!-- Set up a new user coordinate system so that
        the text string's origin is at (0,0), allowing
        rotation and scale relative to the new origin -->
  <g transform="translate(100,100)" >
    <!-- The following illustrates the use of the 'set', 'animateMotion',
         'animateColor' and 'animateTransform' elements. The 'text' element 
         below starts off hidden (i.e., invisible). At 3 seconds, it:
           \* becomes visible
           \* continuously moves diagonally across the viewport
           \* changes color from blue to dark red
           \* rotates from -30 to zero degrees
           \* scales by a factor of three. -->
    <text xml:id="TextElement" x="0" y="0"
          font-family="Verdana" font-size="35.27" visibility="hidden"  > 
      It's alive!
      <set attributeName="visibility" to="visible"
           begin="3s" dur="6s" fill="freeze" />
      <animateMotion path="M 0 0 L 100 100" 
           begin="3s" dur="6s" fill="freeze" />
      <animateColor attributeName="fill"
           from="rgb(0,0,255)" to="rgb(128,0,0)"
           begin="3s" dur="6s" fill="freeze" />
      <animateTransform attributeName="transform" 
           type="rotate" from="-30" to="0"
           begin="3s" dur="6s" fill="freeze" />
      <animateTransform attributeName="transform" 
           type="scale" from="1" to="3" additive="sum"
           begin="3s" dur="6s" fill="freeze" />
    </text>
  </g>
</svg>

![Example 19_01 - at zero seconds](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/animate/anim01a.png) At zero seconds

![Example 19_01 - at three seconds](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/animate/anim01b.png) At three seconds

![Example 19_01 - at six seconds](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/animate/anim01c.png) At six seconds

![Example 19_01 - at nine seconds](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/animate/anim01d.png) At nine seconds

The sections below describe the various animation attributes and elements.

### 16.2.4 Attributes to identify the target element for an animation

The following attributes are common to all [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement) and identify the target element for the animation. If the target element is not capable of being a target of the animation, then the animation has no effect.

Refer to the descriptions of the individual [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement) for any restrictions on what types of elements can be targets of particular types of animations.

**Schema:** animatecommon

    <define name='svg.AnimateCommon.attr'>
      <ref name='svg.XLink.attr'/>
      <ref name='svg.Conditional.attr'/>
    </define>

_Attribute definitions:_

xlink:href = "[<IRI>](#types-DataTypeIRI)"

An [IRI reference](#intro-TermIRIReference) to the element which is the target of this animation and which therefore will be modified over time.

The target element must be part of the [current SVG document fragment](#intro-TermCurrentSVGDocumentFragment). If the target element is not part of the [current SVG document fragment](#intro-TermCurrentSVGDocumentFragment) or the [IRI reference](#intro-TermIRIReference) is otherwise an [invalid IRI reference](#intro-TermInvalidIRIReference), then the animation has no effect. This means the animation timing will still run but no animation effect will be applied to the target attribute.

If the ['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) attribute is not provided, then the target element will be the immediate parent element of the current animation element.

['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) must point to exactly one target element. If ['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) points to multiple target elements then it shall be treated as an [unsupported value](#intro-TermUnsupportedValue) and processed as if the attribute had not been specified. If xlink:href="" (the empty string), it shall be treated as if the ['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) attribute was not specified.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Specifying the animation target](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-SpecifyingAnimationTarget) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

If the ['xml:id'](#struct-xmlIDAttribute) or ['id'](#struct-IDAttribute) attribute of an element that is the target of an animation is changed, then whether this affects the animation is undefined, and implementation dependent. Future specifications will describe in more detail the result of modifying elements that affect [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement) which are already in the document tree.

Resolution of the animation target occurs when the [animation element](#intro-TermAnimationElement) is inserted into the document tree or at the [document begin](#intro-TermDocumentBegin) time, whichever is later. (See also the ['timelineBegin'](#struct-SVGElementTimelineBegin) attribute, which controls when the [document begin](#intro-TermDocumentBegin) time occurs.)

### 16.2.5 Attributes to identify the target attribute or property for an animation

The following attributes identify the target attribute or property for the given [target element](#animate-TargetElement) whose value changes over time.

**Schema:** animateattributecommon

    <define name='svg.AnimateAttributeCommon.attr'>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='attributeName' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <ref name='QName.datatype'/>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='attributeType' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value>XML</value>
            <value>CSS</value>
            <value>auto</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
    </define>

_Attribute definitions:_

attributeName = "[<QName>](#types-DataTypeQName)"

Specifies the name of the target attribute. A qualified name, if used, indicates the XML namespace for the attribute. The prefix will be resolved to a namespace name in the scope of the current (i.e. the referencing) animation element. Note that while the ['attributeName'](#animate-AttributeNameAttribute) attribute is optional, there is no [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue). When no value is specified the animation still runs, and events related to the animation element (e.g. [`beginEvent`](#interact-EventsBegin)) are still fired, but the animation doesn't apply to any attribute.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Specifying the animation target](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-SpecifyingAnimationTarget) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

attributeType = "CSS" | "XML" | "auto"

Specifies the namespace in which the target attribute and its associated values are defined. The attribute value is one of the following (values are case-sensitive):

CSS

This specifies that the value of ['attributeName'](#animate-AttributeNameAttribute) is the name of a [property](#intro-TermProperty) defined as animatable in this specification.

XML

This specifies that the value of ['attributeName'](#animate-AttributeNameAttribute) is the name of an XML attribute on the target element. If the value for ['attributeName'](#animate-AttributeNameAttribute) has a prefix, it is resolved as described [above](#animate-AttributeNameAttribute). If not, then the target attribute is in no namespace. The attribute must be defined as animatable in this specification.

auto

The user agent should match the ['attributeName'](#animate-AttributeNameAttribute) to an animatable property or attribute applicable to the target element. If the user agent supports CSS, it must first search through its list of supported CSS properties (including those not defined by SVG) for a matching property name that is defined to be animatable for the target element. If no suitable property is found, the user agent must then search for a suitable animatable attibute, using the appropriate namespace. If the ['attributeName'](#animate-AttributeNameAttribute) value has no prefix, then the attribute searched for is in no namespace. If it does have a prefix, then that prefix is resolved as described [above](#animate-AttributeNameAttribute) and the attribute searched for in the associated namespace. If no suitable property or attribute is found, the animation has no effect.

Note that not all properties are applicable to all SVG elements, even if an attribute of the same name is applicable to the element. In particular, the CSS 'width' and 'height' properties are not applicable to those SVG elements which have 'width' and 'height' attributes.

The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is 'auto'.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Specifying the animation target](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-SpecifyingAnimationTarget) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.1).

In the absence of style sheets (external style sheets, 'style' elements or 'style' attributes, as may be available in other profiles of SVG) animation of [presentation attributes](#intro-TermPresentationAttribute) is equivalent to animating the corresponding property. Thus, for [properties listed in SVG Tiny 1.2](#styling-SVGStylingProperties), the same effect occurs from animating the presentation attribute with attributeType="XML" as occurs with animating the corresponding property with attributeType="CSS".

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

### 16.2.6 Animation with namespaces

Example animns01 below shows a namespace prefix being resolved to a namespace name in the scope of the referencing element, and that namespace name being used (regardless of the prefix which happens to be used in the target scope) to identify the attribute being animated.

**Example:** [animns01.svg](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/examples/animns01.svg)

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<svg version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
    xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
    <title>Demonstration of the resolution of namespaces for animation</title>
    <!-- at the point of definition, the QName a:href resolves to the namespace 
        name "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" and the local name "href" -->
    <g xmlns:a="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
        <animate attributeName="a:href" xlink:href="#foo" dur="2s" to="two.png" fill="freeze"/>
    </g>
    <!-- at the point of use, the namespace name "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" 
      happens to be bound to the namespace prefix 'b'  while the prefix
      'xlink' is bound to a different namespace name-->
    <g xmlns:b="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:xlink="http://example.net/bar">
        <image xml:id="foo" b:href="one.png" x="35" y="50" width="410" height="160"/>
    </g>
</svg>

### 16.2.7 Paced animation and complex types

Paced animations assume a notion of distance between the various animation values defined by the ['to'](#animate-ToAttribute), ['from'](#animate-FromAttribute), ['by'](#animate-ByAttribute) and ['values'](#animate-ValuesAttribute) attributes. Distance is defined only for scalar types (such as [<length>](#types-DataTypeLength)), colors and the subset of transformation types that are supported by ['animateTransform'](#animate-AnimateTransformElement). In the list of distance functions below, Va and Vb represent the two values the distance between which is being calculated.

Since paced animation is intended to produce an animation with an even pace of change, it does not make sense to define distance functions for all data types. Distance can be usefully defined for types whose values are n\-dimensional vectors (including scalars, which are 1-dimensional vectors). For example, a [<length>](#types-DataTypeLength) value is a scalar value, and a [<color>](#types-DataTypeColor) value is a 3-dimensional vector. Thus attributes of these types can have paced animation applied to them. On the other hand, a [<list-of-length>](#types-DataTypeLengths) (as used by ['stroke-dasharray'](#painting-StrokeDasharrayProperty)) is a list of scalars (1-dimensional vectors), and [<points-data>](#types-DataTypePoints) (as used by the ['points'](#shapes-PolygonElementPointsAttribute) attribute on a ['polygon'](#shapes-PolygonElement)) is a list of 2-dimensional vectors. Therefore, these types do not have a distance function defined and cannot have paced animation applied to them.

The distance functions for types that support paced animation are as follows:

[<coordinate>](#types-DataTypeCoordinate), [<integer>](#types-DataTypeInteger), [<length>](#types-DataTypeLength) and [<number>](#types-DataTypeNumber)

distance(Va, Vb) = |Va − Vb|

Examples: animating the ['x'](#shapes-RectElementXAttribute) attribute on a ['rect'](#shapes-RectElement), or the ['stroke-width'](#painting-StrokeWidthProperty) property on a ['circle'](#shapes-CircleElement).

[<color>](#types-DataTypeSVGColor)

distance(Va, Vb) = sqrt((Va.red − Vb.red)2 + (Va.green − Vb.green)2 + (Va.blue − Vb.blue)2), where:

Vi.red is the red component of the Vi color value,

Vi.green is the green component of the Vi color value, and

Vi.blue is the blue component of the Vi color value.

Each of the color component values is usually in the range \[0, 1\], where 0 represents none of that color component, and 1 represents the maximum amount of that color component, in the sRGB gamut \[[SRGB](#refs-ref-SRGB)\]. Since [<color>](#types-DataTypeSVGColor) values may specify colors outside of the sRGB gamut, these component values may lie outside the range \[0, 1\].

Example: animating the ['fill'](#painting-FillProperty) property on an ['ellipse'](#shapes-EllipseElement).

Transform definitions of type 'translate'

distance(Va, Vb) = sqrt((Va.tx − Vb.tx)2 + (Va.ty − Vb.ty)2), where:

Vi.tx is the x component of the Vi translation transform value, and

Vi.ty is the y component of the Vi translation transform value.

Example (for all transform definition types): animating the ['transform'](#coords-TransformAttribute) attribute on a ['g'](#struct-GElement) using ['animateTransform'](#animate-AnimateTransformElement).

Transform definitions of type 'scale'

distance(Va, Vb) = sqrt((Va.sx − Vb.sx)2 + (Va.sy − Vb.sy)2), where:

Vi.sx is the x component of the Vi scale transform value, and

Vi.sy is the y component of the Vi scale transform value.

Note that, as when specifying scale transformations in a [<transform-list>](#types-DataTypeTransformList), if the y component of the scale is omitted it is implicitly equal to the x component.

Transform definitions of type 'rotate', 'skewX' and 'skewY'

distance(Va, Vb) = sqrt((Va.angle − Vb.angle)2), where:

Vi.angle is the angle component of the Vi rotation or skew transform value.

Since the distance function for rotations is not in terms of the rotation center point components, a paced animation that changes the rotation center point may not appear to have a paced movement when the animation is applied.

Distance functions for all other data types are not defined. If calcMode="paced" is used on an animation of an attribute or property whose type is not one of those listed above, the animation effect is undefined. [SVG user agents](#intro-TermSVGUserAgent) may choose to perform the animation as if calcMode="linear", but this is not required. Authors are recommended not to specify paced animation on types not listed above.

### 16.2.8 Attributes to control the timing of the animation

The following attributes are common to all [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement) and control the timing of the animation, including what causes the animation to start and end, whether the animation runs repeatedly, and whether to retain the end state the animation once the animation ends.

These timing attributes also apply to [media elements](#intro-TermMediaElement).

**Schema:** animatetiming

    <define name='svg.AnimateTiming.attr' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.AnimateTimingNoMinMax.attr'/>
      <optional><attribute name='min' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional><attribute name='max' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
    </define>

    <define name='svg.AnimateTimingNoMinMax.attr' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.AnimateTimingNoFillNoMinMax.attr'/>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='fill' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value>remove</value>
            <value>freeze</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
    </define>

    <define name='svg.AnimateTimingNoFillNoMinMax.attr' combine='interleave'>
      <ref name='svg.AnimateBegin.attr'/>
      <optional><attribute name='dur' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional><attribute name='end' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional><attribute name='repeatCount' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional><attribute name='repeatDur' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='restart' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value>always</value>
            <value>never</value>
            <value>whenNotActive</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
    </define>

    <define name='svg.AnimateBegin.attr' combine='interleave'>
      <optional><attribute name='begin' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
    </define>

In the syntax specifications that follow, optional white space is indicated as "S", defined as follows:

S ::= (#x20 | #x9 | #xD | #xA)\*

_Attribute definitions:_

begin = "_begin-value-list_"

Defines when the element should begin (i.e. become active). The attribute value is a semicolon separated list of timing specifier values.

The definition of _begin-value-list_ is as follows:

begin-value-list ::= [_begin-value_](#animate-BeginValueSyntax) ( S? ";" S? _begin-value-list_ )?

A semicolon separated list of begin values. The interpretation of a list of begin times is detailed in SMIL 2.1 section on ["Evaluation of begin and end time lists"](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-EvaluationOfBeginEndTimeLists).

begin-value ::= ( [_offset-value_](#animate-OffsetValueSyntax) | [_syncbase-value_](#animate-SyncbaseValueSyntax) | [_event-value_](#animate-EventValueSyntax) | [_repeat-value_](#animate-RepeatValueSyntax) | [_accessKey-value_](#animate-AccessKeyValueSyntax) | ["indefinite"](#animate-IndefiniteValue) )

Describes the element begin time.

offset-value ::= ( S? "+" | "-" S? )? ( [<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax) )

For SMIL 2.1, this describes the element begin as an offset from an implicit [syncbase](#intro-TermSyncbase). For SVG, the implicit syncbase begin is defined to be relative to the [document begin](#intro-TermDocumentBegin). Negative begin times are entirely valid and easy to compute, as long as there is a resolved document begin time.

syncbase-value ::= ( Id-value "." ( "begin" | "end" ) ) ( S? ( "+" | "-" ) S? [<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax) )?

Describes a [syncbase](#intro-TermSyncbase) and an optional offset from that [syncbase](#intro-TermSyncbase). The element begin is defined relative to the begin or active end of another animation. A [syncbase](#intro-TermSyncbase) consists of an ID reference to another animation element followed by either .begin or .end to identify whether to synchronize with the beginning or active end of the referenced animation element.

event-value ::= ( Id-value "." )? ( event-ref ) ( S? ( "+" | "-" ) S? [<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax) )?

Describes an event and an optional offset that determine the element begin. The animation begin is defined relative to the time that the event is dispatched to the [event-base element](#animate-event-baseElement). The list of event names available for use as the event-ref value can be found in the "Animation event name" column of the [Complete list of supported events](#interact-SVGEvents) table. Details of event-based timing are described in the [Unifying event based and scheduled timing](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-Appendix-Unifying) section of [SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.11).

repeat-value ::= ( Id-value "." )? "repeat(" [<integer>](#types-DataTypeInteger) ")" ( S? ( "+" | "-" ) S? [<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax) )?

Describes a qualified repeat event and an optional offset that will begin the element. The element begin is defined relative to the time that the [`repeatEvent`](#interact-RepeatEvent) event is dispatched to the [event-base element](#animate-event-baseElement) with the iteration value specified by the integer, which must be positive.

accessKey-value ::= "accessKey(" character ")" ( S? ( "+" | "-" ) S? [<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax) )?

Describes a key press event and an optional offset that will begin the element. The element begin is defined relative to the time of the [`keydown`](#interact-EventsKeydown) event corresponding to the specified key. From a formal processing model perspective, an accessKey-value corresponds to a [`keydown`](#interact-EventsKeydown) event listener on the document which behaves as if [`stopPropagation()`](#svgudom-events__Event_stopPropagation) and [`preventDefault()`](#svgudom-events__Event_preventDefault) have both been invoked in the capture phase. (See [Event flow](#interact-EventFlow) for consequences of this behavior.)

The character value can be one of two types. It can be any of the keyboard event identifier strings listed in the [key identifiers set](#svgudom-KeyIdentifiersSet). Alternatively, this value can be a single Unicode character \[[UNICODE](#refs-ref-UNICODE)\]. In this case, the single character is mapped to a keyboard identifier for the purpose of processing the accessKey-value event listener. For example, 'accessKey(Q)' will translate into a [`keydown`](#interact-EventsKeydown) event listener using "U+0051" as the target keyboard identifier string, as if 'accessKey(U+0051)' were used.

"indefinite"

The begin of the animation will be determined by a [`beginElement()`](#svgudom-smil__ElementTimeControl_beginElement) method call or a hyperlink targeted to the element. (Hyperlink-based timing is described in [SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization: Hyperlinks and timing](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-HyperlinksAndTiming).)

In SVG, if no ['begin'](#animate-BeginAttribute) is specified, the default timing of the time container is equivalent to an offset value of '0'. If the ['begin'](#animate-BeginAttribute) attribute is syntactically invalid, in the list itself or in any of the individual list values, it is equivalent to a single ['begin'](#animate-BeginAttribute) value of 'indefinite'.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [basic timing support](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-BasicTiming) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization. See also the special parsing rules for Id-value and event-ref as described in the [Parsing timing specifiers](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-ParsingTimeSpecifiers) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

dur = "[<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax)" | "media" | "indefinite"

Specifies the simple duration. The attribute value can one of the following:

[<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax)

Specifies the length of the simple duration in [document time](#intro-TermDocumentTime). Value must be greater than 0.

media

Specifies the simple duration as the intrinsic media duration. This is only valid for elements that define media.

For SVG's [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement), if 'media' is specified, the attribute will be ignored.

indefinite

Specifies the simple duration as indefinite.

If the animation does not have a ['dur'](#animate-DurAttribute) attribute, the simple duration is indefinite. Note that interpolation will not work if the simple duration is indefinite (although this may still be useful for ['set'](#animate-SetElement) elements).

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Dur value semantics](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-DurValueSemantics) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

end = "_end-value-list_"

Defines an end value for the animation that can constrain the active duration. The attribute value is a semicolon separated list of values.

end-value-list ::= [_end-value_](#animate-EndValueSyntax) (S? ";" S? end-value-list )?

A semicolon separated list of end values. The interpretation of a list of end times is detailed below.

end-value ::= ( [_offset-value_](#animate-OffsetValueSyntax) | [_syncbase-value_](#animate-SyncbaseValueSyntax) | [_event-value_](#animate-EventValueSyntax) | [_repeat-value_](#animate-RepeatValueSyntax) | [_accessKey-value_](#animate-AccessKeyValueSyntax) | "indefinite" )

Describes the active end of the animation.

A value of 'indefinite' specifies that the end of the animation will be determined by an [`endElement()`](#svgudom-smil__ElementTimeControl_endElement) method call.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [basic timing support](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-BasicTiming) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization. See also the special parsing rules for Id-value and event-ref as described inthe [Parsing timing specifiers](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-ParsingTimeSpecifiers) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

min = "[<Clock-value>](#types-DataTypeClock-value)" | "media"

Specifies the minimum value of the active duration. The attribute value can be either of the following:

[<Clock-value>](#types-DataTypeClock-value)

Specifies the length of the minimum value of the active duration, measured in local time.

The value must be greater than 0.

media

Specifies the minimum value of the active duration as the intrinsic media duration. This is only valid for elements that define media.

For SVG's [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement), if 'media' is specified, the attribute will be ignored.

The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) for ['min'](#animate-MinAttribute) is '0'. This does not constrain the active duration at all.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [More control over the active duration](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-MinMax) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization. (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

max = "[<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax)" | "media"

Specifies the maximum value of the active duration. The attribute value can be either of the following:

[<Clock-value>](#animate-ClockValueSyntax)

Specifies the length of the maximum value of the active duration, measured in local time.

The value must be greater than 0.

media

Specifies the maximum value of the active duration as the intrinsic media duration. This is only valid for elements that define media.

For SVG's [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement), if 'media' is specified, the attribute will be ignored.

There is no [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) for ['max'](#animate-MaxAttribute). If omitted, the active duration is not constrained at all.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [More control over the active duration](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-MinMax) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization. (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

restart = "always" | "whenNotActive" | "never"

always

The animation can be restarted at any time. This is the [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue).

whenNotActive

The animation can only be restarted when it is not active (i.e. after the active end). Attempts to restart the animation during its active duration are ignored.

never

The element cannot be restarted for the remainder of the current simple duration of the parent time container. (In the case of SVG, since the parent time container is the [SVG document fragment](#intro-TermSVGDocumentFragment), the animation cannot be restarted for the remainder of the document duration.)

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in [The restart attribute](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-restartAttribute) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

repeatCount = "[<number>](#types-DataTypeNumber)" | "indefinite"

Specifies the number of iterations of the animation function. It can have the following attribute values:

[<number>](#types-DataTypeNumber)

This is a (base 10) "floating point" numeric value that specifies the number of iterations. It can include partial iterations expressed as fraction values. A fractional value describes a portion of the [simple duration](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-SpecifyingAnimationFunction) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.2). Values must be greater than 0.

indefinite

The animation is defined to repeat indefinitely (i.e. until the document ends).

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Repeating elements](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-repeatSyntax) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

repeatDur = "[<Clock-value>](#types-DataTypeClock-value)" | "indefinite"

Specifies the total duration for repeat. It can have the following attribute values:

[<Clock-value>](#types-DataTypeClock-value)

Specifies the duration in [document time](#intro-TermDocumentTime) to repeat the animation function [`**f(t)**`](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-SimpleAnimationFunction) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.3.1).

"indefinite"

The animation is defined to repeat indefinitely (i.e. until the document ends).

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Repeating elements](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#adef-repeatDur) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

fill = "freeze" | "remove"

This attribute can have the following values:

freeze

The animation effect [`**f(t)**`](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-SimpleAnimationFunction) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.3.1) is defined to freeze the effect value at the last value of the active duration. Note that in the case of discrete animation, the frozen value that is used is the value of the animation just before the end of the active duration. The animation effect is "frozen" for the remainder of the document duration (or until the animation is restarted — see [The restart attribute](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-restartAttribute) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

remove

The animation effect is removed (no longer applied) when the active duration of the animation is over. After the active end of the animation, the animation no longer affects the target (unless the animation is restarted — see [The restart attribute](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-restartAttribute) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

This is the [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue).

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Extending an element](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-fillAttribute) section of SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

SMIL 2.1 defines the detailed processing rules associated with the above attributes.

#### event-base element

_This section is informative._

For a normative definition of event-base elements, see the [SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3) and the [Multimedia](#chapter-multimedia) section of this specification. For [animation elements](#intro-TermAnimationElement) and the ['discard'](#struct-DiscardElement) element, the default event-base element is the animation target, which for elements with an ['xlink:href'](#animate-HrefAttribute) attribute is the target [IRI](#intro-TermIRIReference), and is otherwise the parent element. The default event-base element for all SVG [media elements](#intro-TermMediaElement) (e.g. ['audio'](#multimedia-AudioElement), ['video'](#multimedia-VideoElement) and ['animation'](#multimedia-AnimationElement)) is the element itself. For all event-values that are prefaced with an Id-value, the event-base element is the element indicated by that ID.

Authoring note: non-rendered elements such as the ['audio'](#multimedia-AudioElement) element cannot receive user-initiated pointer events, so it is recommended that authors specify a rendered element as the event-base element for such cases when using [user interface events](#interact-UIEvents).

#### Clock values

Clock values have a subsetted syntax of the [clock values syntax defined in SMIL 2.1](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-ClockValueSyntax) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.1):

Clock-val         ::= Timecount-val
Timecount-val     ::= Timecount ("." Fraction)? (Metric)?
Metric            ::= "s" | "ms"
Fraction          ::= DIGIT+
Timecount         ::= DIGIT+
DIGIT             ::= \[0-9\]

For timecount values, the default metric suffix is "s" (for seconds). No embedded white space is allowed in clock values, although leading and trailing white space characters will be ignored.

Clock values describe [document time](#intro-TermDocumentTime).

The following are examples of legal clock values:

*   Timecount values:  
      `30s`     = 30 seconds  
      `5ms`     = 5 milliseconds  
      `12.467`  = 12 seconds and 467 milliseconds

Fractional values are just (base 10) floating point definitions of seconds. Thus:

`00.5s = 500 milliseconds`

### 16.2.9 Attributes that define animation values over time

The following attributes are common to elements ['animate'](#animate-AnimateElement), ['animateMotion'](#animate-AnimateMotionElement), ['animateColor'](#animate-AnimateColorElement) and ['animateTransform'](#animate-AnimateTransformElement). These attributes define the values that are assigned to the target attribute or property over time. The attributes below provide control over the relative timing of keyframes and the interpolation method to be used between particular values.

**Schema:** animatevalue

    <define name='svg.AnimateToCommon.attr' combine='interleave'>
      <optional><attribute name='to' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
    </define>

    <define name='svg.AnimateValueCommon.attr'>
      <ref name='svg.AnimateToCommon.attr'/>
      <optional>
        <attribute name='calcMode' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'>
          <choice>
            <value>discrete</value>
            <value>linear</value>
            <value>paced</value>
            <value>spline</value>
          </choice>
        </attribute>
      </optional>
      <optional><attribute name='values' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional><attribute name='keyTimes' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional><attribute name='keySplines' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional><attribute name='from' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
      <optional><attribute name='by' svg:animatable='false' svg:inheritable='false'><text/></attribute></optional>
    </define>

_Attribute definitions:_

calcMode = "discrete" | "linear" | "paced" | "spline"

Specifies the interpolation mode for the animation. This can take any of the following values. The [lacuna value](#intro-TermLacunaValue) is 'linear', except on ['animateMotion'](#animate-AnimateMotionElement) elements where it is 'paced'. However if the target attribute does not support interpolation (e.g. when animating an attribute whose type is [<string>](#types-DataTypeString)), the ['calcMode'](#animate-CalcModeAttribute) attribute is ignored and discrete animation is used.

discrete

This specifies that the animation function will jump from one value to the next without any interpolation.

linear

Simple linear interpolation between values is used to calculate the animation function.

paced

Defines interpolation to produce an even pace of change across the animation. This is only supported for the data types for which there is an appropriate distance function defined, which includes only scalar numeric types plus the types listed in [Paced animation and complex types](#animate-complexDistances). If 'paced' is specified, any ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) or ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) will be ignored. Authors are discouraged from using paced animation on types that do not have a distance function defined, due to its unpredictable behavior in some user agents.

spline

Interpolates from one value in the ['values'](#animate-ValuesAttribute) list to the next according to a time function defined by a cubic Bézier spline. The points of the spline are specified in the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) attribute, and the control points for each interval are specified in the ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) attribute.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Simple animation function attributes](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#adef-calcMode) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.2).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

values = "[<list>](#types-DataTypeList)"

A semicolon-separated list of one or more values. Vector-valued attributes are supported using the vector syntax of the ['attributeType'](#animate-AttributeTypeAttribute) domain.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Simple animation function attributes](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#adef-values) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.2). Note that, per the SMIL specification, leading and trailing white space, and white space before and after semi-colon separators, is allowed and will be ignored.

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

keyTimes = "[<list>](#types-DataTypeList)"

A semicolon-separated list of time values used to control the pacing of the animation. Each time in the list corresponds to a value in the ['values'](#animate-ValuesAttribute) attribute list, and defines when the value is used in the animation function. Each time value in the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) list is specified as a floating point value between 0 and 1 (inclusive), representing a proportional offset into the simple duration of the animation element.

If a list of ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) is specified, there must be exactly as many values in the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) list as in the ['values'](#animate-ValuesAttribute) list.

Each successive time value must be greater than or equal to the preceding time value.

The ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) list semantics depends upon the interpolation mode:

*   For linear and spline animation, the first time value in the list must be 0, and the last time value in the list must be 1. The ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) value associated with each value defines when the value is set; values are interpolated between the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute).
    
*   For discrete animation, the first time value in the list must be 0. The time associated with each value defines when the value is set; the animation function uses that value until the next time defined in ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute).
    

If the interpolation mode is 'paced', the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) attribute is ignored.

If the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) attribute has a value that doesn't conform to the above requirements the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) attribute has an [unsupported value](#intro-TermUnsupportedValue) and is processed as if the attribute had not been specified.

If the simple duration is indefinite, any ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) specification will be ignored.

Because paced animation interpolation is unspecified for some value types, authors are encouraged to use 'linear' animation interpolation with calculated ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) to achieve particular interpolation behavior for these types.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Calculation mode attributes](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#adef-keyTimes) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.8.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

keySplines = "[<list>](#types-DataTypeList)"

A set of Bézier control points associated with the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) list, defining a cubic Bézier function that controls interval pacing. The attribute value is a semicolon separated list of control point descriptions. Each control point description is a set of four values: `x1 y1 x2 y2`, describing the Bézier control points for one time segment. Note SMIL 2.1 allows these values to be separated either by commas with optional white space, or by white space alone. The ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) values that define the associated segment are the Bézier "anchor points", and the ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) values are the control points. Thus, there must be one fewer set of control points than there are ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute).

The values must all be in the range 0 to 1.

This attribute is ignored unless the ['calcMode'](#animate-CalcModeAttribute) is set to 'spline'.

If the ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) attribute has a value that doesn't conform to the above requirements the ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) attribute has an [unsupported value](#intro-TermUnsupportedValue) and is processed as if the attribute had not been specified.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Calculation mode attributes](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#adef-keySplines) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.8.1).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

from = "<value>"

Specifies the starting value of the animation.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Simple animation functions specified by from, to and by](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#adef-from) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.4).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

to = "<value>"

Specifies the ending value of the animation.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Simple animation functions specified by from, to and by](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#adef-to) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.4).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

by = "<value>"

Specifies a relative offset value for the animation.

Except for any SVG-specific rules explicitly mentioned in this specification, the normative definition for this attribute is found in the [Simple animation functions specified by from, to and by](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#adef-by) section of the SMIL 2.1 Animation Modules (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.4).

[Animatable](#animate-Animatable): no.

SMIL 2.1 defines the detailed processing rules associated with the above attributes.

The animation values specified in the ['values'](#animate-FromAttribute), ['from'](#animate-FromAttribute), ['to'](#animate-ToAttribute) and ['by'](#animate-ByAttribute) attributes must be legal values for the specified target attribute. Leading and trailing white space, and white space before and after semicolon separators, will be ignored. If any values are not legal, they are considered to be [unsupported](#intro-TermUnsupportedValue) and is processed as if they had not been specified.

If a list of ['values'](#animate-ValuesAttribute) is used, the animation will apply the values in order over the course of the animation. If the ['values'](#animate-ValuesAttribute) attribute is specified, any ['from'](#animate-FromAttribute), ['to'](#animate-ToAttribute) or ['by'](#animate-ByAttribute) attribute values are ignored.

The processing rules for the variants of from/to/by animations, including which of the ['from'](#animate-FromAttribute), ['to'](#animate-ToAttribute) and ['by'](#animate-ByAttribute) attributes take precedence over the others, is described in [Simple animation functions specified by from, to and by](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/animation.html#animationNS-AnimationFunctionValueDetails) (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 3.5.4).

When animating properties, interpolation is performed on computed values. Thus, keywords such as inherit which yield a numeric computed value may be included in the values list for an interpolated animation. For example, a linear animation of the ['fill'](#painting-FillProperty) property using values="red; inherit; blue" is possible as long as the inherit value does not compute to a paint server reference, a system paint or the none value.

The following figure illustrates the interpretation of the ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) attribute. Each diagram illustrates the effect of ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) settings for a single interval (i.e. between the associated pairs of values in the ['keyTimes'](#animate-KeyTimesAttribute) and ['values'](#animate-ValuesAttribute) lists). The horizontal axis can be thought of as the input value for the _unit progress_ of interpolation within the interval, i.e. the pace with which interpolation proceeds along the given interval. The vertical axis is the resulting value for the _unit progress_, yielded by the ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) function. Another way of describing this is that the horizontal axis is the input _unit time_ for the interval, and the vertical axis is the output _unit time_. See also the [Timing and real-world clock times](http://www.w3.org/TR/2005/REC-SMIL2-20051213/smil-timing.html#Timing-TimingAndRealWorldClockTime) section in SMIL 2.1 Timing and Synchronization (\[[SMIL21](#refs-ref-SMIL21)\], section 10.4.3).

Examples of ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute)

![Example keySplines01 - keySplines of 0 0 1 1 (the default)](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/animate/keySplines01.png)  
keySplines="0 0 1 1"  
(the default)

![Example keySplines01 - keySplines of .5 0 .5 1](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/animate/keySplines02.png)  
keySplines=".5 0 .5 1"

![Example keySplines01 - keySplines of 0 .75 .25 1](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/animate/keySplines03.png)  
keySplines="0 .75 .25 1"

![Example keySplines01 - keySplines of 1 0 .25 .25](https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-SVGTiny12-20081222/images/animate/keySplines04.png)  
keySplines="1 0 .25 .25"

To illustrate the calculations, consider the simple example:

<animate dur="4s" values="10; 20" keyTimes="0; 1"
     calcMode="spline" **keySplines**\="_{as in table}_"/>

Using the ['keySplines'](#animate-KeySplinesAttribute) values for each of the four cases above, the approximate interpolated values as the animation proceeds are:
